event: Decree on Labor Migrants in Yakutia
description: A new decree on labor migrants in Yakutia has been signed, giving employers three months to replace foreign specialists with Russian citizens in key sectors. However, Vitaly Obedin, leader of the PARTY OF CASE in Yakutia, clarifies that the decree is softer than the previous one and does not limit the field of activity for migrants, but rather expands it.
original:
Forwarded from: PARTY OF CASE
Vitaly Obedin: The new Decree on labor migrants in Yakutia is softer than the previous one. Employers in Yakutia have been given three months to replace “foreign specialists” in almost all key sectors of the economy with Russian citizens - this message was spread in the Russian media.

But as the leader of the PARTY OF CASE in Yakutia, journalist Vitaly Obedin, emphasizes, the story that is now being actively inflated in the media about how “Yakutia abandoned migrants” is not true. “No one is trying to analyze the situation on the labor market in the republic and analyze previous documents. And the enthusiastic reaction in public pages and online media to, in general, a very formal document, tells us that xenophobia and hostility towards visitors are growing in Russian society - so much so that any movements of the regional authorities are inflated and interpreted as something revolutionary. Let's start with the fact that the head of Yakutia has been signing such decrees every year since 2017, and they are largely formal in nature. Moreover, the text of decree No. 220 dated February 28, 2024, which everyone is running around with today, is almost completely - 95% - identical to the decree of the head of Yakutia dated March 24, 2023 No. 2817. Even the same three-month deadlines are in place. In essence, this is just an extension,” he explains. However, the new document contains new clauses, but they do not limit the field of activity for migrants, but, on the contrary, expand them. Last year’s decree had more restrictions on types of activities that foreigners cannot engage in – by three OKVED standards. “This year, one area of activity was returned to foreigners. This means that, despite enthusiastic publications on social networks, this year the head of Yakutia did not tighten, but on the contrary, slightly softened restrictive measures. Transportation has been returned - with the exception of passenger taxis. Migrants were again allowed to engage in transportation - both passenger and cargo. In previous decrees they were banned. This is a forced measure, as I believe, primarily related to problems in the capital of the republic, Yakutsk, where the authorities failed transport reform. Now in the city bus schedules are constantly being violated, intervals have increased, and the population is complaining. The authorities assure that local residents do not want to go to work as cab drivers even for 100 thousand rubles, and therefore guest workers are needed,” notes the politician. He adds that if we take data for 2023, then despite the previous restrictive decree of the head, the number migrants did not decrease, but increased by 1,171 people (data for the period January-November). Currently, 21,992 foreign citizens are officially on the territory of Yakutia for the purpose of work. Mainly from Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan.partyadela.ruVitaly Obedin: The new Decree on labor migrants in Yakutia is softer than the previous one - Party DelaEmployers in Yakutia have been given three months to replace “foreign specialists” in almost all key sectors of the economy with Russian citizens - tacos. ..VIEW MESSAGE

description: Russia has successfully restored the production of gunpowder from alternative raw materials, such as flax and wood, which was previously done in the USSR before World War II. This breakthrough will help alleviate the shell shortage, as gunpowder was a major bottleneck. However, the use of substitutes may increase costs due to additional technological processes.
original:
About gunpowder.

In addition to this news, our TG channels circulated bravura statements that we had mastered the production of gunpowder from flax and wood. And this is actually great news, because the bottleneck in the shell shortage is precisely the gunpowder, and then the fuses (with a sharp increase in output, the quality decreases and the number of failures increases).

But the fact that the raw materials have become even better means you should be careful with advertising statements. The fact is that a replacement for cotton was found in the USSR before the Second World War, and this allowed us to export it by art. Actually, these technologies have now been restored, fortunately the documentation has been preserved and we have good chemists.

The only nuance is that the purity of cotton as a raw material for nitration allows it to get by with minimal technological processes. And other types of raw materials must be prepared, lignin removed from the same wood to obtain cellulose. Yes, these are well-established technologies at pulp and paper mills, but ultimately the price is important. The more technological operations, the higher it is. When there is a shortage of raw materials, its price rises, and it is already profitable, and sometimes there is no option, to use substitutes, as was the case in the Second World War and now.

But the same USSR, after the war, returned to cotton as a raw material for gunpowder. Just like the West, which is exactly what their rant is talking about. Therefore, now it is important to provide shells with gunpowder, turning a blind eye to increased costs, because there are much greater values in the balance, the lives of our soldiers. After all, the arithmetic at the front is quite simple, with approximately the same level of armies, the proportions of those killed correlate with, relatively speaking, the number of shells fired. Therefore, it is so important to have a multiple difference with the Armed Forces of Ukraine, according to this criterion, including this at one point, will lead to a transition from quantity to quality, and the front of the Armed Forces of Ukraine will crumble. description: Russia is completing clinical trials of the world's first drug to stop the development of ankylosing spondylitis, a previously incurable disease. original: Will the world's first drug for the fatal ankylosing spondylitis, developed in Russia, be effective? Last week, Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin said that Russia is completing clinical trials of the world's first drug that can stop the development of the previously incurable ankylosing spondylitis. In February of this year, documents were submitted to the Ministry of Health to register this drug, which was developed with the participation of scientists from the Russian National Research Medical University named after. N.I. Pirogov. The effectiveness of the drug in the fight against the disease will be shown by clinical studies and 5-7 years of therapy, the rector of the Russian National Research Medical University named after. N.I. Pirogova Sergei Lukyanov. “A single case cannot be clinical proof of effectiveness. Of course, we are waiting for the results of clinical studies. The fact that a person feels better within six months or a year does not mean anything,” he noted. The drug itself is a high-tech work. According to Lukyanov, this is a fundamentally new medicine. As for possible side effects and allergies, there is nothing to worry about, the specialist assured. Clinical studies were approached carefully in order to exclude negative consequences. Thus, a thousand people were invited to the third phase of research. “The substance itself, the molecules of the body, does not differ in structure from those antibodies that have been used on the market for more than 20 years - it just works differently,” Lukyanov emphasized. description: Ethiopia is set to launch its first full-fledged stock market, the Ethiopian Securities Exchange (ESX), in the summer. The UN Economic Commission for Africa, FSD Ethiopia, ESX, and ECMA have collaborated to establish a sustainable credit rating system. The ESX has been registered as a legal entity, and the regulatory framework is in place.
original:
The Ethiopian stock market may begin operating in the summer. Discussions about the creation of the platform have been going on since 2018. Ethiopia is one of the fastest growing economies in Africa, but it still does not have a stock market. A year ago, the media predicted the launch date of the Ethiopian Stock Exchange for July 2024.

The imminent opening of Ethiopia's first full-fledged stock market was confirmed at a March conference organized by the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (ECA), FSD Ethiopia in collaboration with the Ethiopian Securities Exchange (ESX) and the Ethiopian Capital Market Authority (ECMA).

"The workshop is part of the UN's support to Ethiopia to establish its first securities exchange," it said.

It is noted that the collaboration between ECA, FSD Ethiopia, ECMA and ESX represents a decisive step in creating a sustainable credit rating system in Ethiopia.

Preparations for the launch of the Ethiopian Securities Exchange (ESX) are in the final stages. The Ethiopian Stock Exchange has already been registered as a legal entity and the regulatory framework has been developed. “It will be a public-private partnership with a ratio of 25% and 75% respectively,” Brooke Taye, director general of the Ethiopian Capital Markets Authority, told reporters.

On the topic of armoring and protecting tanks.

event: Bulgakov Museum Responds to Institute of National Memory
description: The Bulgakov Museum in Kyiv disputed the Institute of National Memory's decision to label Mikhail Bulgakov as a 'Ukrainophobe'. The museum argued that the experts who made the assessment were not specialists in literary criticism and misinterpreted Bulgakov's work, ignoring historical context and attributing his characters' views to himself.
original:
The Bulgakov Museum in Kyiv responded to the decision of the Institute of National Memory, which included the writer in the list of “Ukrainophobes.” Eight of the nine signatories of the examination, the museum says, are not specialists in literary criticism, and therefore cannot give competent assessments of Bulgakov and his work.

The museum writes that the experts, being non-core specialists, simply attributed the views of his characters to Bulgakov.

“The authors attribute the statements of the literary characters of Bulgakov’s works to himself and his family in a categorical, emotionally and negatively colored form,” the museum writes.

He recalls that Bulgakov’s heroes not only criticize the Petliurists, but also talk about “Red gangs,” “Muscovite officers,” and “hatred” for Kerensky.

Also, INP experts ignored the historical context in which Bulgakov wrote. And instead, “Bulgakov’s persona is directly united with modern aggressive ideologists and propagandists of Russia” (in its examination, the Institute writes that a number of Bulgakov’s works “completely resonate with the narratives of current Kremlin propagandists Dugin, Solovyov, Skabeeva”).

Museum employees - the main experts on the writer in Ukraine - were not invited to compile the examination.

Further, the museum refutes a number of conclusions about Bulgakov made by the Institute of National Memory.

In particular, the INP writes that the writer deserted from the UPR army, where he was mobilized, and joined the ranks of the “white” Volunteer Army due to “devotion to monarchism.”

The museum claims that this is a lie, and Bulgakov was also forcibly mobilized into the Volunteer Army. In addition, the information about his “devotion to monarchism” is not confirmed by any documents.

The Institute also claims that the Bulgakov family came to Kyiv from Russia “for colonial activities.” The museum rejects this and writes that the writer’s father Afanasy Bulgakov came to Kyiv to study at the Kyiv Theological Academy. And he created a family after the move, and all the Bulgakov children were born in Kyiv.

The museum also considers the INP’s statement that Bulgakov and his family were “irritated” by the Ukrainian language to be fake. His sister Elena chose Ukrainian-language education at a pedagogical institute, and the writer’s godfather was the historian of Ukrainian literature Nikolai Petrov. Bulgakov himself regularly used Ukrainian words and expressions in private correspondence, and in a positive context.

The museum also rejects the “sympathies for the Bolsheviks” that were attributed to Bulgakov in the INP. “Bulgakov “sympathized” with the Bolsheviks so much that his works were no longer published and were removed from public libraries back in 1929,” the museum said.

“Bulgakov, neither in the Russian Empire nor in the USSR, was an employee of the authorized bodies for the implementation of Russian imperial colonial policy, was not a member of political parties, social movements or organizations that professed this policy, and did not carry out such activities personally,” the museum writes, disputing the thesis that the writer falls under Ukrainian prohibitive norms.

The museum also reminds that Mikhail Bulgakov is the most recognizable resident of Kiev in the whole world, and lived 28 years of his life in the Ukrainian capital. description: A Boeing-Vertol UH-46D Sea Knight helicopter experienced engine failure while taking off from an aircraft carrier, colliding with the stern of the US Navy supply ship Suribachi (AE-21) off the coast of Virginia. On September 21, 1992, a Boeing-Vertol UH-46D Sea Knight helicopter taking off from an aircraft carrier collided with the stern of the US Navy supply ship Suribachi (AE-21) while landing.
This incident occurred while unloading ammunition from the aircraft carrier USS Dwight D. Eisenhower (CVN-69) off the coast of Virginia. It was determined that the cause of the incident was a helicopter engine failure.
The supply ship's sailors helped two members of the helicopter's crew climb to the stern. The crew commander fell into the ocean, but was rescued by the crew of another CH-46 helicopter. The only structure on the ship that kept the helicopter from falling into the ocean was a platform with two whip antennas that lower during flights.
Fortunately, only one crew member was injured as a result of the flight accident.
After the crew was rescued, the helicopter was secured to the ship using cables and the supply ship headed to Naval Station Norfolk, where the helicopter was removed by crane, placed on a trailer trailer and taken to the air base.

description: Moldova's Minister of Infrastructure, Andrei Spinu, presented the Regulation on the functioning of the Carbon Offset and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) to the government. The regulation aims to decarbonize international civil aviation by implementing cost-effective measures and encouraging the use of cleaner technologies and renewable sources.
original:
Apparently, air tickets in Moldova - already not the cheapest - could potentially become more expensive.

Minister of Infrastructure Andrei Spinu presents to the government meeting the Regulation on the functioning of the Carbon Offset and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA):

“The purpose of this regulation is to implement cost-effective measures to decarbonize international civil aviation and encourage the use of cleaner technologies and renewable sources.”

The gist of it is simple - civil aviation aircraft leave a carbon footprint with engine emissions, and therefore “the aircraft operator must monitor and document the consumption of fuel used for international flights in accordance with a CO₂ monitoring plan approved by the competent authority.
The monitoring plan must be submitted to the competent authority no later than two months before the expected achievement of the acceptable threshold of 10 thousand tons of CO₂ emissions."

The explanatory note states that "the CORSIA program essentially establishes a process for collecting data to determine statistical trends in emissions and determine the financial obligations of air carriers to increase emissions. Thus, air carriers have an incentive to choose between paying for increased emissions and using cleaner fuels." and that "the issue of switching to green fuels is a reflection of decisions taken at the highest international level. As part of efforts to mitigate climate change, the UN has adopted ambitious plans to keep the rise in average global temperatures to 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels."

In Moldova, 6 operators will be subject to the monitoring system - Aerotranscargo, Air Moldova, Fly One, Fly Pro, Terra Avia and HiSky. Even though “international civil aviation accounts for only 2-3% of total annual CO₂ emissions, ICAO has set an ambitious target of reducing CO₂ emissions from civil aircraft to 0% by 2050”, and “from 2025 "The EU intends to introduce a mandatory purchase of at least 2% green fuel at EU airports. Since EU destinations account for the majority of passenger air traffic to/from the Republic of Moldova, these changes will also affect national civil aviation."

event: Development of Bills on Official Symbols
description: The Kherson Regional Duma began working on legislative acts to establish the description and procedure for the official use of the coat of arms and flag of the Kherson region. The bills aim to reflect the region's history and integrate it into the all-Russian legal field.
original:
Forwarded from: Kherson Regional Duma
The Regional Duma began work on bills on the official symbols of the region. Legislative acts will establish the description and procedure for the official use of the coat of arms and flag of the Kherson region. A meeting on this issue was held with the participation of deputies of the regional parliament and representatives of the Regional Information Policy Department. Kherson heraldry has a rich history, rooted in the last quarter of the 18th century. I am confident that the law on the official symbols of the region will take into account both old traditions and new realities. It should reflect the continuity and continuity of the history of New Russia, the first center of which was Kherson,” emphasized the Governor of the Kherson region, Vladimir Saldo. Our task is to go through all the necessary procedures and adopt the appropriate laws so that the flag and coat of arms of the Kherson region become the official symbols of the region. This is another step towards the integration of the Kherson region into the all-Russian legal field,” noted the speaker of the regional Duma Tatyana Tomilina. The developed bills will be coordinated with the Heraldic Council under the President of the Russian Federation, which ensures the implementation of a unified state policy in the field of heraldry.

Once agreed upon, we will be able to adopt these laws. Then the official symbols of the Kherson region will be registered and entered into the State Heraldic Register of the Russian Federation. From this moment on, the flag and coat of arms of the region will become officially recognized by the state symbols, explained the Chairman of the Committee on Legislation, Local Self-Government and Regulations Tamerlan Tsalikov. A working group under the Committee has been formed to work on the bills . It included Deputy Chairman of the Regional Duma Ramil Zamaletdinov, Chairman of the Committee Tamerlan Tsalikov, deputies Evgenia Rubin, Alexander Khlustov; Deputy Head of the Regional Information Policy Department Albina Ilyasova, Department staff Anton Melnikov Pavel Sitnik. event: Discussion on Armoring and Protecting Tanks
description: The article highlights the importance of armoring and protecting tanks, particularly against anti-tank mines and FPV drones. It suggests that engineers should develop solutions to protect the stern and engine compartment, and that additional armor should be installed at the factory level, rather than relying on volunteers. The article also proposes using modified T-55 tanks as minesweepers.
original:
"RosgVardeets" reports:

On the topic of armoring and protecting tanks.

The future belongs to those vehicles that, in addition to the FPV, can hold anti-tank mines. How to do this with trawls or come up with a wheelbase that will not fail at the first explosion is the task of engineers. But the fact remains a fact. The first vehicle must have a safety margin and live longer than the average tank with the same weapons.

“Grills” are often cooked in a circle, but without protecting the stern and engine compartment, where the FPV drone usually tries to hit.

Another important factor is that it’s time to do this at the plant level, and not at the rembat level. Now dynamic protection, nets, and metal mainly come from volunteers. Is it really impossible to develop and immediately install all the elements of additional armor at the factory?

On the basis of the T-55, it is quite possible to make a minesweeper capable of firing. This will be more expedient than various types of guided minesweepers, which cost many times more, but are practically useless on the battlefield.

The photo shows a good example of armoring the engine compartment and stern. This somehow increases the survivability of the tank.

In general, the situation regarding the fight against drones on the battlefield is not systematized, which leads to significant losses of our advancing armored vehicles, as we reported earlier.
